statement.tex: %text Using integration, find the area of the region enclosed between the two circles $x^2+y^2=4$ and $(x-2)^2 + y^2 = 4$. %
\\ \textbf{Where are the circles?} \\ %text Which of the figures below shows the two circles drawn correctly? %
\\ \textbf{Points of intersection} \\ %text What are the coordinates of the points $P$ and $Q$ where the two circles intersect? %
\\ %text Your friend makes the following assertions (see figure) about the required area $A$. \textbf{Are his assertions correct?} %
\\ %text In Step 3, we established that \[ A = 4a = 4b=4c=4d \] Given this, can we say the following? %

reason.tex:
%text A circle centered at $(a,b)$ has the equation \[ (x-a)^2 + (y-b)^2 = R^2 \]
And so, by this logic % \begin{align} x^2 + y^2 &= 4 \implies \text{center} = (0,0) \\ (x-2)^2 + y^2 &= 4 \implies \text{center} = (2,0) \\ \end{align} \\ %text Hence, we should have one circle centered at the origin $O$ and another circle \underline{\text{to the right}} of it (at $(2,0)$). %

%text The two circles will intersect when % \begin{align} y^2 &= 4-x^2 = 4-(x-2)^2 \\ \implies x^2 = (x-2)^2 &\text{ or }\underbrace{x^2-(x-2)^2}_{a^2-b^2 = (a-b)\cdot(a+b)} = 0 \\ \implies [x-(x-2)] &\cdot [x+(x-2)] = 0 \\ \implies 4\cdot (x-1) &= 0\text{ or } x=1 \\ \therefore \underbrace{P = (1,\sqrt{3})}_{(x,y) = (x,\sqrt{4-x^2})}&\text{ and }Q = (1,-\sqrt{3}) \end{align}

\textbf{Look for symmetry} \\ %text The line $PQ\perp$ x-axis. And together they divide the required area $A$ into four segments \textit{- a,b,c and d}.
But notice also the symmetry in the figure.
Both circles have a radius of 2 units.
The center of both circles lies on the x-axis.
Each circle passes through the center of the other circle.
There is therefore \underline{\text{no reason to believe}} that $a\neq b\neq c\neq d$. In fact, we can safely say that $a=b=c=d$ because of symmetry. %

%text If you look at the figure in Step 3 again, then you will notice that % \begin{align} A &= 4\cdot\underbrace{\int_0^1 \sqrt{4-(x-2)^2}\cdot dx}_{a} \\ &= 4\cdot \underbrace{\int_1^2 \sqrt{4-x^2}\cdot dx}_{b} \\ \end{align} \\ %text Evaluating \[b=\int_1^2 \sqrt{4-x^2}\cdot dx\] just looks easier. So let us do that now. % \begin{align} A &= 4\cdot \int_1^2 \underbrace{\sqrt{4-x^2}}_{\sqrt{2^2-x^2}}\cdot dx \\ &= 4\cdot\underbrace{\left[ \dfrac{2^2}{2}\sin^{-1}\dfrac{x}{2} + x\cdot\sqrt{2^2-x^2}\right]_1^2}_ {\int\sqrt{a^2-x^2}\cdot dx = \frac{a^2}{2}\sin^{-1}\frac{x}{a}+x\cdot\sqrt{a^2-x^2}}\\ &= 4\cdot \left[ \left( 2\sin^{-1}\frac{2}{2} + 0\right) - \left( 2\sin^{-1}\frac{1}{2}+\sqrt{3}\right) \right]\\ &= 4\cdot\left[ 2\cdot\frac\pi{2} - 2\frac\pi{6} - \sqrt{3}\right] = \frac{8\pi}{3}-4\sqrt{3} \end{align}
